## Empirical results

In this section, I present the main empirical findings of the thesis. The objective is to compare different factor models in the context of the cryptocurrency market in order to study the dynamics of cryptocurrency returns. This is carried out within the IPCA framework by estimating models under several specifications: the general IPCA with purely latent factors, models with observable factors and static loadings, and models with observable factors and dynamic loadings (with characteristics instrumenting loadings). Results are reported for different choices of $K$ factors. In addition, I evaluate model performance using the total and predictive scores, both in-sample and out-of-sample. Finally, I examine which cryptocurrency characteristics from the panel data make a significant individual contribution to the overall model fit.

The models and tests described in this section are implemented in Python 3.13.5, using the code provided by Seth Pruitt ^[See https://sethpruitt.net/research/.]. I adapted this code by adding the Wald-type tests with bootstrap procedures, following the implementation in the `ipca` python package of @ipca ^[See https://bkelly-lab.github.io/ipca/.]. All figures are generated using the Matplotlib package [v. 3.10.3\; @Hunter:2007]. 

Following @kellyCharacteristicsAre2019, I cross-sectionally standardize the instrument characteristics to mitigate their sensitivity to outliers. Period-by-period, I rank the cryptocurrencies according to each characteristic. Then, I standardize these ranks by dividing them by the number of non-missing observations and subtract 0.5. This transformation maps each characteristic to the interval $[-0.5, 0.5]$, reducing the influence of extreme values while preserving the relative ordering across assets. In addition, all characteristics are lagged and computed up to time $t-1$, i.e., one day prior to the return prediction, and are calculated on a rolling-window basis when necessary. Consequently, the characteristics observed at date $d-1$ determine the exposures associated with the returns realized at date $d$. 


### IPCA asset pricing performance

I estimate the IPCA model with $K = 1, \dots, 6$ factors, considering the restricted ($\Gamma_\alpha = \mathbf{0}$) and the unrestricted specification $\Gamma_\alpha \neq \mathbf{0}$). Panel A in @tbl-ipca_results presents the in-sample performance of the IPCA models estimated at the individual cryptocurrency level. As noted in @sec-methodology, the IPCA is estimated from a least squares criterion, targeting directly the total $R$ and the latent factors are optmized to describe the systematic risk among assets. As a consequence, adding more factors to the specification will increase the total R, as wee see in the table, starting from 3.87% in the one-factor model and reaching 9.07% in the six-factor model, with the increment in total R becoming lower and lower as we add more factors. However, allowing for $\Gamma_\alpha \neq 0$ increases considerably the total $R$, nearly doubling the results compared to the restricted model. The gap between the unrestricted and the restricted model shrinks as we add more factors. However, the unrestricted model still nearly doubles the total $R$ compared to the restricted model. However, when observing the predictive $R$, the results for the one-factor model is much larger for the one-factor model, while the others are relatively similar. This suggests that adding the anomaly intercepts contributes in explaining the realized return variation, but the small increment in the predictive R suggests that characteristics through anomaly intercepts barely contributes to explain the cryptocurrency returns. We confirm this when looking at @tbl-alphatest, which reports the $p$-values of the asset-pricing test which tests the null hyporthesis of $\Gamma_\alpha = \mathbf{0}$, the anomaly intercept not being statistically significant to explain the returns beyond the exposure to systematic risks. The results indicated that the null cannot be rejected across all $K$ factor models.

Alpha tests

```{=latex}
\begin{table}
\centering
\small
\caption[Asset-pricing test]%
{%
\textbf{Asset-pricing test.}
The table reports bootstrapped $p$-values (in percent) for testing whether anomaly intercepts explain returns beyond systematic risk exposures. Specifically, the null hypothesis $H_{0}: \Gamma_{\alpha} = \mathbf{0}$ is tested against the alternative $H_{1}: \Gamma_{\alpha} \neq \mathbf{0}$, using $b = 1, \dots, 1000$ bootstrap simulations. Rejecting the null indicates that characteristics contribute to expected returns through anomaly intercepts, in addition to their role in determining exposures to risk.
}
\label{tbl-alphatest}
\vspace{5pt} % extra space between caption and tabular

 &  1 & 2 & 3 & 4 & 5 & 6 \\
\midrule\addlinespace[2.5pt]
$W_\alpha$ $p$-value        & 0.84 & 0.82 & 0.23 & 0.31 & 0.34 & 0.03 \\
\bottomrule
\end{tabular}
\end{table}
```

## Which characteristics matter? 



Here reference @fig-charsheatmap

![**Significant characteristics**. The figure shows which cryptocurrency characteristics are significant in explaining factor loadings across IPCA models with $K=1,\dots,6$ latent factors in the restricted specification $\Gamma_\_alpha = \mathbf{0}$. The null hypothesis is that the coefficients for a characteristic, $\Gamma_{\beta,l}$, are zero, meaning it has no effect after controlling for the other characteristics. Colors indicate significance at the 1%, 5%, and 10% levels based on Wald-type tests.](pictures/chars_heatmap.png){#fig-charsheatmap fig-scap="Significant characteristics"}
